nodes.text: The training date interlock panel sits at chest height. (pause) Bolted to the corridor wall like an apology. (pause) Its screen is lit. The green light is off.
On-screen: TRAINING STATUS: NOT CURRENT. Subtext: LOTO ACCESS WITHHELD PENDING DATE-SHAPED VERIFICATION.
Before you do anything with that panel—this is recorded for training and assurance purposes. Not yours. Ours.
If you’re seeing “Not Current,” that means the system cannot confirm you are currently trained, which is different from you being untrained. It’s a documentation state. It’s not— it’s not an insult.
It’s blocking LOTO.
Correct. Because LOTO is a behavior, and behavior requires currency. Not because you’re unsafe. Because we can’t prove you’re safe. There’s a difference that matters in a deposition.
The panel emits a quiet chirp, like it wants you to feel responsible for it.

choices.text: (ask) "Why is a date gate on a lock point?"
(use) Apply a token sticker to the reader.

nodes.text: You wait. The intercom clicks, as if someone moved a cup off a button.
I can walk you through acceptable methods. Acceptable as in “accepted by the interlock.” Not “endorsed by me personally,” just so we’re clean.
Scratched optical reader. Faded label: “TRAINING: ENTER DATE / PRESENT PROOF.” DATE underlined twice, tearing laminate.
What does it want?
A date. Not a metaphorical date. Not “I did the training in spirit.” A date the panel can parse.

It will accept: a current training record via badge lookup, a stamped completion card, or a signed waiver with the correct wording. Correct wording meaning the wording Legal fought for, not the wording Safety prefers.
Badge lookup?
Unavailable. Network segmentation. Which is— it’s deliberate. It’s not negligence. It’s containment. Different budget line.
The “Not Current” message does not change.
Why is a date gate on a lock point?
Because the lock point is an interface, and interfaces are where people improvise. The date gate stops improvisation by forcing you to improvise in a documented manner.
Also, historically, someone bypassed a lock with a wrench and then claimed the lock was “confusing.” So now the lock is very clear. In the most inconvenient way possible.
The panel flashes a warning icon: “USER ENGAGED: PROVIDE PROOF.” It feels accusatory, but it’s pixels.
Override it. I’m OLEA.
I hear you. And for the record, I respect the title. But this unit doesn’t have an “override,” it has an “acceptable alternate.” Language matters.

If I tell you “go ahead,” and the panel still logs “Not Current,” then we’ve created a conflict between spoken instruction and hardware log. And hardware logs win. They always win. They don’t get nervous on the stand.
So. Use the waiver if you have it. Or present a token the reader will accept. Those are your two clean paths— clean as in traceable.
Show waiver.

You hold the signed waiver up to the panel camera. (pause) The paper is creased where it’s been folded and unfolded too many times. (pause) The signature block is darker, like someone pressed too hard.
Okay— yes. That’s the waiver format. And just to be explicit: a waiver is not “approval,” it’s “assumption of risk.” Which sounds like the same thing until someone gets ambitious.
The panel scans. It takes longer than it should, like delay is part of the lesson.
On-screen: WAIVER VERIFIED. Then: TRAINING STATUS: CONDITIONALLY CURRENT.
Conditionally current. That’s good. That’s as good as it gets in this building.
Green light clicks on. Relay behind wall thunks. Panel: ACCESS RESTORED. PROCEED TO LOTO MAIN LOCK-POINT.
Proceed. And— just— don’t make me say “good job” on a recording.
Use sticker.
You peel a small token sticker—glossy, date-colored, made because printers lie—from its backing strip. (pause) You place it over the optical reader’s worn window.
I need to state, for the record, that I did not instruct you to— I’m seeing what you’re doing. I’m not telling you to do it.
The panel is very literal. If it sees a date-shaped token, it will log a date-shaped compliance event. Which is… not fraud. It’s a substitution. Different words. Less prison.
The reader pulses red, then amber, then— as if embarrassed— green.
On-screen: TOKEN ACCEPTED. Then: TRAINING STATUS: CURRENT (LOCAL).
Local current. Great. That means it will satisfy this interlock and annoy an auditor later, specifically one with time.
If anyone asks: the system accepted an approved token. Do not say “sticker.” “Sticker” sounds like a craft.

The green light clicks on. (pause) The corridor feels unchanged. (pause) The lock logic is willing to pretend you exist now. (pause) The panel displays: ACCESS RESTORED. PROCEED TO LOTO MAIN LOCK POINT.
Leave.

You step back. (pause) The panel keeps its screen lit, waiting to be satisfied. (pause) It does not time out. (pause) It just holds a grudge politely. (pause) You are still in the Operations Corridor. (pause) The training gate remains uncleared.
A phone number is printed in the corner, with the confidence of a signature. (pause) You dial. (pause) After three tones, someone picks up like they were already speaking.

Before you say anything: if this is about the training date, it is not “expired.”
“Expired” implies it was valid for a duration we agreed on. We never agreed on that.

choices.text: Ask: The panel says “out of range.”
Persuade: Give me the policy window and who can authorize an update.

nodes.text:
Correct. “Range” is the safe word we use when Legal is in the room.
Your training record has a date. The interlock reads the date.
The date does not match the current approved date window for work that could be interpreted as—
I’m not saying you’re doing it. I’m saying the interlock can’t know your heart.

Officially? A training update, processed, posted, and ingested by the interlock system.
Unofficially? I am not allowed to have unofficially.

Also, do not write “I needed access.” Write “access required by closure checklist.” That phrasing holds up better.

Policy Rev 7B defines the window; it’s not a calendar concept, it’s a risk classification concept.
Authorization is routed through Records for changes that touch interlock ingestion.
If you quote me: quote the document, not my mouth.

No. If I say the window out loud, it becomes advice.
You want the policy text. You do not want me.

The line stays open half a second too long, like they’re waiting to be quoted. (pause)
Then it ends decisively, as if you dialed them by mistake.
